content: The Act titled "Securing America's Energy Independence Act of 2007" extends and modifies the investment tax credit for solar energy and qualified fuel cell property. The Act "Securing America's Energy Independence Act of 2007" extends and modifies the investment tax credit for solar energy and qualified fuel cell property. Amendments include updating the years for solar energy and fuel cell property eligibility, and expanding energy property to include excess energy storage devices and solar hybrid lighting systems. The Act "Securing America's Energy Independence Act of 2007" extends and modifies the investment tax credit for solar energy and qualified fuel cell property. Amendments include updating the years for solar energy and fuel cell property eligibility, and expanding energy property to include excess energy storage devices and solar hybrid lighting systems. Section 48(a)(3)(A) of the Code is amended to include equipment using solar energy for fiber-optic distributed sunlight illumination. Additionally, a special rule for solar photovoltaic energy property credits is introduced, with a credit of $1,500 for each half kilowatt of capacity placed in service during the taxable year. The Act extends the investment tax credit for solar energy and fuel cell property, with a special rule for solar photovoltaic energy property credits of $1,500 per half kilowatt capacity. Amendments include updating eligibility years and expanding energy property to include excess energy storage devices and solar hybrid lighting systems. Special rules apply to rehabilitated or subsidized property. The amendments made by this section will be effective on January 1, 2007, except for property placed in service after December 31, 2006. Extension and modification of credit for residential energy efficient property. Extension and modification of the residential energy efficient property tax credit include amending the termination date to 2016, removing the 30 percent allowance for solar electric property, and setting maximum credits for different types of qualified property expenditures. The definition of qualified solar water heating property expenditure is amended to include heating, cooling, or providing hot water. The definition of qualified photovoltaic property expenditure is expanded to include advanced energy storage systems. The credit allowed against alternative minimum tax is capped at the sum of regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55. The tax credit for qualified solar water heating and photovoltaic property expenditures is capped at the sum of regular tax liability and the tax imposed by section 55. Unused credits can be carried forward to the next taxable year. Amendments are made to various sections of the tax code to accommodate these changes. Section 26(a)(1) of the tax code is amended to include section 25D. These changes apply to expenditures after December 31, 2006. SEC. 4. 3-YEAR ACCELERATED DEPRECIATION PERIOD FOR SOLAR ENERGY PROPERTY AND FUEL CELL PROPERTY. The text chunk discusses amendments to the Internal Revenue Code related to property descriptions for tax purposes. It includes changes to clauses (iv) and (v) of section 168(e)(3) and a conforming amendment to section 168(e)(3)(B)(vi)(I) regarding wind and solar energy properties. The amendments made by this section apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2006.
